{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} {{atheism2}} {{Status of religious freedom}} '''Discrimination against atheists''' (sometimes called '''atheophobia''')<ref>{{cite magazine | year = 1987 | title = Atheophobia: An Introduction | first = Robert L. | last = Rafford | magazine = Religious Humanism | volume = 21 | publisher = Fellowship of Religious Humanists | page = 33 | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=fI_XAAAAMAAJ&dq=atheophobia | quote = Atheophobia is pathological, and similar in nature to homophobia. It is unconscious, internalized, and taught from early years on.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | year = 2003 | month = Spring | title = Inviting Atheists to the Table: A Modest Proposal for Higher Education | first = Robert J. | last = Nash | journal = [[Religion & Education]] | issn = 1550-7394 | volume = 30 | issue = 1 | location = New York | doi = 10.1080/15507394.2003.10012315 | passage = Atheophobia is the fear and loathing of atheists that permeate American culture. }}</ref> includes the [[Religious persecution|persecution]] and [[Religious discrimination|discrimination]] faced by [[atheism|atheists]] and those labeled as atheists in the past and in the current era. Differing definitions of atheism historically and culturally mean those discriminated against might not be considered truly atheist by modern Western standards.
In constitutional democracies, legal discrimination against atheists is uncommon, but some atheists and atheist groups, particularly those in the [[United States]], have protested laws, regulations and institutions they view as being discriminatory. In some Islamic countries, atheists face discrimination including lack of legal status or even a [[capital punishment#Islam|death sentence]] in the case of [[apostacy in Islam|apostasy]].
==Ancient times== Historians including [[Lucien Febvre]] agree atheism in its modern sense did not exist before the end of the seventeenth century.<ref name="davidson">{{cite book|last=Davidson|first=Nicholas|title=Atheism from the Reformation to the Enlightenment|editor=Michael Hunter; David Wootton|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1992|pages=55–86|chapter=Unbelief and Atheism In Italy|isbn=978-0-19-822736-6}}</ref><ref name="books.google">{{cite book|last=Armstrong |first=Karen |title=A History of God: The 4000-year Quest of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam |publisher=Random House, Inc. |pages=286–87|year=1994|url= http://books.google.com/?id=_n3cCF2I2FUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=A+History+of+God| isbn=978-0-345-38456-0}}</ref><ref name="kelley">{{cite book|last=Kelley|first=Donald R. |title=Frontiers of History: Historical Inquiry in the Twentieth Century |publisher=Yale University Press|year=2006|page=115|isbn=978-0-300-12062-2|url=http://books.google.com/?id=K-wVctit5U8C&pg=PA115}}</ref> However, as governmental authority rested on the notion of [[Divine right of kings|divine right]], it was threatened by those who denied the existence of the local god. Philosophers such as [[Plato]] argued that atheism (as we understand it today) was a danger to society and should be punished as a crime.<ref name="gey 250">{{cite book|last=Gey|first=Steven G.|title=The Cambridge Companion to Atheism|editor=Martin, Michael|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|chapter=Atheism and the Freedom of Religion|pages=250–253, 260–2 |isbn=978-0-521-84270-9|url=http://books.google.com/?id=tAeFipOVx4MC&pg=PA250}}</ref> Those labeled as atheist, which included early Christians and Muslims, were as a result targeted for legal persecution.<ref name="gey 250"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Armstrong |first=Karen |title=A History of God: The 4000-year Quest of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam |publisher=Random House, Inc. |pages=98, 147|year=1994|url= http://books.google.com/?id=_n3cCF2I2FUC&printsec=frontcover|isbn=978-0-345-38456-0}}</ref>
==Early modern period and Reformation== During the [[Early modern period]], the term "atheist" was used as an insult and applied to a broad range of people, including those who held opposing theological beliefs, as well as suicides, immoral or self-indulgent people, and even opponents of the belief in witchcraft.<ref name="davidson"/><ref name="books.google"/><ref name="laursen">{{cite book|last=Laursen|first=John Christian |coauthors=Nederman, Cary J.|title=Beyond the Persecuting Society: Religious Toleration Before the Enlightenment |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|year=1997|page=142|isbn= 978-0-8122-1567-0|url=http://books.google.com/?id=r2j6ZHgXZWkC&pg=PA142}}</ref> Atheistic beliefs were seen as threatening to order and society by philosophers such as [[Thomas Aquinas]]. Lawyer and scholar [[Thomas More]] said that religious tolerance should be extended to all except those who did not believe in a deity or the immortality of the soul.<ref name="gey 250"/> [[John Locke]], a founder of modern notions of religious liberty, argued that atheists (as well as Catholics and Muslims) should not be granted full citizenship rights.<ref name="gey 250"/>
During the Inquisition, several of those accused of atheism or blasphemy, or both, were tortured or executed. These included a priest [[Giulio Cesare Vanini]] who was strangled and burned in 1619 and a Polish nobleman [[Kazimierz Łyszczyński]] who was executed in Warsaw,<ref name="davidson"/><ref name="brooke">{{cite book|last= Brooke|first=John Hedley|others= Maclean, Ian |title=Heterodoxy in Early Modern Science and Religion |publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-19-926897-9|url=http://books.google.com/?id=W9o_OEvMQTcC&pg=PA66}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Kłoczowski |first=Jerzy |title=A History of Polish Christianity |publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2000 |page=155|isbn=978-0-521-36429-4|url=http://books.google.com/?id=ecdye8hk_tgC&pg=PA155}}</ref> as well as [[Etienne Dolet]], a Frenchman executed in 1546. Though heralded as atheist martyrs during the nineteenth century, recent scholars hold that the beliefs espoused by Dolet and Vanini are not atheistic in modern terms.<ref name="kelley"/><ref name="onfray">{{cite book|last=Onfray|first=Michel|others=Leggatt, Jeremy (translator) |title=Atheist manifesto: the case against Christianity, Judaism, and Islam |publisher=Arcade Publishing|year=2007|page=24|isbn=978-1-55970-820-3|url=http://books.google.com/?id=QpEAYMo7pFkC&pg=PA24}}</ref><ref name="chadwich">{{cite book|last=Chadwick |first=Owen |title=The Early Reformation on the Continent By |publisher= Oxford University Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-19-926578-7|url=http://books.google.com/?id=VR1yNW8mgoEC&pg=PA413}}</ref>
==Modern era== During the nineteenth century, British atheists, though few in number, were subject to discriminatory practices.<ref name="cookson">{{cite book | author = Larson, Timothy| chapter= Victorian England | title = Encyclopedia of religious freedom | editor= Cookson, Catharine| publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 2003 | isbn = 0-415-94181-4 | oclc = }}</ref> Those unwilling to swear Christian oaths during judicial proceedings were unable to give evidence in court to obtain justice until the requirement was repealed by Acts passed in 1869 and 1870.<ref name="cookson"/> In addition, the poet [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]] was expelled from the University of Oxford and denied custody of his two children after publishing a pamphlet on ''[[The Necessity of Atheism]]''.<ref name="gey253" />
Atheist [[Charles Bradlaugh]] was elected as a [[Member of Parliament (UK)|Member of the British Parliament]] in 1880. He was denied the right to affirm rather than swear his oath of office, and was then denied the ability to swear the oath as other Members objected that he had himself said it would be meaningless. Bradlaugh was re-elected three times before he was finally able to take his seat in 1886 when the Speaker of the House permitted him to take the oath.<ref name="gey253">{{cite book|last=Gey|first=Steven G.|title=The Cambridge Companion to Atheism|editor=Martin, Michael|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|chapter=Atheism and the Freedom of Religion|pages=253–255|isbn=978-0-521-84270-9|url=http://books.google.com/?id=tAeFipOVx4MC&pg=PA253}}</ref>
===Nazi Germany=== In Germany during the Nazi era, a 1933 decree stated that "No National Socialist may suffer detriment... on the ground that he does not make any religious profession at all".<ref name="Baynes"/> However, the regime strongly opposed "godless communism",<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Christian|title=Disruptive religion: the force of faith in social-movement activism|publisher=Routledge|year=1996|pages=156–57|isbn=978-0-415-91405-5|url=http://books.google.com/?id=39SoSG4NGAoC&pg=PA156}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Stackelberg|first=Roderick|title=The Routledge Companion to Nazi Germany |publisher=Routledge|year=2007|pages=136–8|isbn=978-0-415-30860-1|url=http://books.google.com/?id=cpXIR9yOMuoC&pg=PA136}}</ref> and most of Germany's atheist and largely left-wing [[freethought]] organizations were banned the same year; some right-wing groups were tolerated by the Nazis until the mid 1930s.<ref name="may">{{cite book |last= Bock| first= Heike | chapter= Secularization of the modern conduct of life? Reflections on the religiousness of early modern Europe| editor=Hanne May |title=Religiosität in der säkularisierten Welt |publisher=VS Verlag fnr Sozialw |year=2006 |page= 157|isbn=3-8100-4039-8 |oclc= |url= http://books.google.com/?id=nfQ0pqA53Z8C&pg=PA157}}</ref><ref name=kaiser>{{cite book|last=Kaiser|first=Jochen-Christoph|title=Atheismus und religiöse Indifferenz|editor=Christel Gärtner|publisher=VS Verlag|year=2003|volume=Organisierter Atheismus|pages= 122, 124–6|isbn=978-3-8100-3639-1|url=http://books.google.com/?id=YXOr4xQFSJsC&pg=PA124}}</ref> During negotiations leading to the Nazi-Vatican Concordat of April 26, 1933 Hitler stated that "Secular schools can never be tolerated" because of their irreligious tendencies.<ref>Ernst Helmreich, ''[http://books.google.com/books?id=I6DYAAAAMAAJ The German Churches Under Hitler]''. Detroit: Wayne State Univ. Press, 1979, p. 241.</ref> In a speech made later in 1933, Hitler claimed to have "stamped [Gottlosenbewegung] out".<ref name="Baynes">{{cite book|last=Baynes|first=Norman Hepburn|title=The Speeches of Adolf Hitler, April 1922 – August 1939'|publisher=H. Fertig|year=1969|page=378|quote= Without pledging ourselves to any particular Confession, we have restored faith to its pre-requisites because we were convinced that the people needs [sic] and requires [sic] this faith. We have therefore undertaken the fight against the atheistic movement, and that not merely with a few theoretical declarations: we have stamped it out. }}</ref> The word Hitler used, "Gottlosenbewegung", refers specifically to the communist freethought movement, not atheism in general.<ref>{{cite web|author=wissenmedia GmbH, München, Germany |url=http://www.wissen.de/wde/generator/wissen/ressorts/geschichte/index,page=1112656.html |title=Gottlosenbewegung |publisher=wissen.de |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref>
==Contemporary era==
===Western countries=== Modern theories of constitutional democracy assume that citizens are intellectually and spiritually autonomous and that governments should leave matters of religious belief to individuals and not coerce religious beliefs using sanctions or benefits. The constitutions, human rights conventions and the religious liberty jurisprudence of most constitutional democracies provides legal protection of atheists and agnostics. In addition, freedom of expression provisions and legislation separating church from state also serve to protect the rights of atheists. As a result, open legal discrimination against atheists is not common in most Western countries.<ref name="gey 250" /> However, prejudice against atheists does exist in Western countries. A [[UBC|University of British Columbia]] study found that believers distrust atheists as much as [[rapist]]s. The study also showed that atheists have lower employment prospects.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www2.psych.ubc.ca/~will/Gervais%20et%20al-%20Atheist%20Distrust.pdf|title=Do You Believe in Atheists? Distrust Is Central to Anti-Atheist Prejudice|first1=Will M.|last1=Gervais|first2=Azim F.|last2=Shariff|first3=Ara|last3=Norenzayan|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|year=2011|volume=101|issue=6|pages=1189–1206|accessdate=April 22, 2012}}</ref>
====Europe==== In most of Europe, atheists are elected to office at high levels in many governments without controversy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ibka.org/en/articles/miz08/politics-religion-usa|title="Most American secularists have few expectations..." An Interview with AAI president Stuart Bechman |last=Hartmann|first=René|date=March 2008|work=MIZ Magazine|accessdate=2009-03-14}}</ref> Some atheist organizations in Europe have expressed concerns regarding issues of separation of church and state, such as administrative fees for leaving the Church charged in Germany,<ref> {{cite web |url=http://ibka.org/en/fee-european-court |title=Fee for leaving church is brought before European Court of Human Rights | I |publisher=International League of Non-religious and Atheists (IBKA) |accessdate=2009-03-14}} </ref> and sermons being organized by the Swedish parliament.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.jo.se/Page.aspx?MenuId=106&MainMenuId=106&Language=sv&ObjectClass=DynamX_SFS_Decision&Id=2100 |title=Anmälan till JO – Riksdagens ombudsmän |publisher=jo.se |accessdate=2009-03-14 }} </ref> Ireland requires religious training from Christian colleges in order to work as a teacher in government funded schools.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2010/0202/1224263575172.html |title=Why must agnostics be obliged to teach faith? |work=The Irish Times |accessdate=2010-02-02 |date=2 February 2010}}</ref> In the UK one third of state-funded schools are faith based;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.runnymedetrust.org/uploads/publications/Summaries/RightToDivide-Summary.pdf|title=Right to Divide? Faith Schools and Community Cohesion|last=Berkeley|first=Rob|coauthors=Savita Vij|date=December 2008|publisher=[[Runnymede Trust]]|page=4|accessdate=7 December 2011|location=London}}</ref> however, there are no restrictions on atheists holding public office: the [[Deputy Prime Minister]], [[Nick Clegg]], is an atheist.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peev |first=Gerri |url=http://news.scotsman.com/politics/I-don39t-believe-in-God.3607087.jp |title=Religion: I don't believe in God |work=The Scotsman |date= 20 December 2007|accessdate=14 April 2010 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref> According to a 2012 poll, 25% of the [[Turks in Germany]] believe atheists are inferior human beings.<ref>Liljeberg Research International: [https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf ''Deutsch-Türkische Lebens und Wertewelten 2012''], July/August 2012, p. 68</ref><ref>[[Die Welt]]: [http://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article108659406/Tuerkische-Migranten-hoffen-auf-muslimische-Mehrheit.html ''Türkische Migranten hoffen auf muslimische Mehrheit''], 17 August 2012, retrieved 23 August 2012</ref>
====Canada==== {{Expand section|date=April 2010}} Canadian [[secular humanist]] groups have worked to end the recitation of prayers during government proceedings, viewing them as discriminatory.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.humanistcanada.com/no-prayers-in-ont-legislature |title=No More Prayers in Legislature |publisher=humanistcanada.com |accessdate=2009-03-14 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com/article/423192|title=Stirring up yet another religious storm|last=Hurst|first=Lynda|date= 9 May 2008 |work=Toronto Star|accessdate=2009-03-14}}</ref>
====United States==== [[File:Why_Do_Atheists_Hate_America_billboard.jpg|thumb|right|Billboard posted in Chambersburg, Pennsylvania in February 2008]] Discrimination against atheists in the United States occurs in legal, social and professional contexts. Some American atheists compare their situation to the discrimination faced by ethnic minorities, [[LGBT]] communities, and women.<ref name="dawkins" /><ref name="Harris">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/sunday/commentary/la-op-harris24dec24,0,3481836.story?coll=la-sunday-commentary|title= 10 myths – and 10 truths – about atheism|last=Harris|first=Sam|date=24 December 2006 |work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2009-03-12}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="fi-md">{{cite journal | title = Discrimination against atheists: the facts | author = Downey, Margaret | authorlink = Margaret Downey | journal = [[Free Inquiry]] | volume = 24 | issue = 4 | month = June–July | year = 2004 | pages = 41–43|url= http://www.secularhumanism.org/library/fi/downey_24_4.htm }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ffrf.org/fttoday/1995/december95/zellner.html|title=Deep In The Bible Belt – One Atheist Professor's Experience|last=Zellner|first=William W. |date=December 1995|work=Freethought Today |accessdate=2009-10-13}}</ref> "Americans still feel it's acceptable to discriminate against atheists in ways considered beyond the pale for other groups," asserted [[Fred Edwords]] of the [[American Humanist Association]].<ref name="AHA"> {{cite web |url=http://www.americanhumanist.org/press/petestark |title=Humanists Praise Pete Stark for "Coming Out" as a Nontheist |publisher=American Humanist |accessdate=2009-03-17 }} </ref> However, other atheists reject these comparisons, arguing that while [[Freedom of religion in the United States#Situation of atheists|atheists may face disapproval]] they have not faced significant oppression or discrimination.<ref name="thornton">{{cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/opinion/la-oew-thornton18apr18,0,5841004.story|title=Disliked, not oppressed I may be a reviled atheist, but that doesn't mean I can claim equal victimhood with truly repressed minorities |last=Thornton|first=Paul|date= 18 April 2007 |work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2009-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Grothe|first=D.J.|coauthors=Dacey, Austin|title=Atheism Is Not a Civil Rights Issue|journal=Free Inquiry|volume=24|issue=2|url=http://www.secularhumanism.org/library/fi/grothe-dacey_24_2.htm}}</ref>
In the United States, six state constitutions officially include religious tests that would effectively prevent atheists from holding public office, and in some cases being a juror/witness, though these have not generally been enforced since the early nineteenth century.<ref name="acl" /><ref>{{cite book|last=Giacalone|first=Robert A|coauthors=Jurkiewicz, Carole L. |title=Handbook of Workplace Spirituality and Organizational Performance |publisher=M.E. Sharpe|year=2005 |isbn=978-0-7656-1743-9|url=http://books.google.com/?id=jlRv-eYAOlMC&pg=PA247}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Urofsky|first=Melvin I.|title=Religious Freedom: Rights and Liberties Under the Law |publisher=ABC-CLIO|year= 2002 |pages=39–40|isbn=978-1-57607-312-4|url=http://books.google.com/?id=7urB3-9TfUIC&pg=PA40}}</ref> The [[United States Constitution|U.S. Constitution]] allows for an [[Affirmation in law|affirmation]] instead of an [[oath]] in order to accommodate atheists and others in court or seeking to hold public office.<ref name="acl" /><ref name="csm">{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2006/1207/p01s03-uspo.html?s=u|title=At swearing in, congressman wants to carry Koran. Outrage ensue|last=Lampman|first=Jane |date=7 December 2006 |work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=2009-03-01}}</ref> In 1961, the [[United States Supreme Court]] explicitly overturned the Maryland provision in the [[Torcaso v. Watkins]] decision, holding that laws requiring "a belief in the existence of God" in order to hold public office violated freedom of religion provided for by the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution]].<ref name="acl">{{cite book|last=West|first=Ellis M.|title=Encyclopedia of American Civil Liberties |editor= Finkelman, Paul|publisher=CRC Press|year=2006|pages= 1314–5|chapter=Religious Tests of Office-Holding|url=http://books.google.com/?id=YoI14vYA8r0C&pg=PA1314|isbn=978-0-415-94342-0}}</ref><ref name="acl119">{{cite book|last=Douglas|first=Davison M.|title=Encyclopedia of American Civil Liberties |editor= Finkelman, Paul|publisher=CRC Press|year=2006|page= 119|chapter=Belief-Action Distinction in Free Exercise Clause History|url=http://books.google.com/?id=YoI14vYA8r0C&pg=PA119|isbn=978-0-415-94342-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Belknap|first=Michal R.|title=The Supreme Court Under Earl Warren, 1953–1969 |publisher= Univ of South Carolina Press|year=2005|isbn=978-1-57003-563-0|url=http://books.google.com/?id=x7UIUme1JYYC&pg=PA136}}</ref> This decision is generally understood to also apply to witness oaths.<ref>{{cite book|last=Friedman |first=Dan|title=The Maryland State Constitution: A Reference Guide |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=2005|page=44|isbn=978-0-313-32044-6|url=http://books.google.com/?id=MoTGJ8bk11wC&pg=PA44&lpg=PA44}}</ref>
Several American atheists have used court challenges to assert discrimination against atheists. [[Michael Newdow]] challenged inclusion of the phrase "under God" in the United States [[Pledge of Allegiance]] on behalf of his daughter, claiming that the phrase was discriminatory against non-theists.<ref name="bishop">{{cite book|last=Bishop|first=Ronald|title=Taking on the Pledge of Allegiance: The News Media and Michael Newdow's Constitutional Challenge |publisher=SUNY Press|year=2007|pages=39–40|isbn=978-0-7914-7181-4|url=http://books.google.com/?id=T6v-hpqD654C&pg=PA39}}</ref> He won the case at an initial stage, but the Supreme Court dismissed his claim, ruling that Newdow did not have [[standing (law)|standing]] to bring his case, thus disposing of the case without ruling on the constitutionality of the pledge.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/americas/3806181.stm|title=US to keep 'under God' pledge|date=14 June 2004|work=BBC News |accessdate=2009-03-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-8128948_ITM|title=U.S. Supreme Court Dismisses Pledge Challenge|last=Mintz|first=Howard|date=15 June 2004|work= San Jose Mercury News |accessdate=2009-03-13}}</ref> Respondents to a survey were less likely to support a kidney transplant for hypothetical atheists and agnostics needing it, than for Christian patients with similar medical needs.<ref>[http://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/zuckerman/Zuckerman_on_Atheism.pdf Atheism, Secularity, and Well-Being: How the Findings of Social Science Counter Negative Stereotypes and Assumptions, Phil Zuckerman*]</ref> As the [[Boy Scouts of America]] does not allow atheists as members, atheist families and the [[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]] from the 1990s onwards have launched a [[Boy Scouts of America membership controversies|series of court cases arguing discrimination against atheists]]. In response to ACLU lawsuits, the Pentagon in 2004 ended sponsorship of [[Scouting]] units,<ref>[http://www.aclu-il.org/legal/courtdocuments/2004/11/winkler_v_chicago_school_refor.shtml Winkler v. Chicago School Reform Board]{{dead link|date=December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/opa/pr/2004/November/04_civ_751.htm |title=Department of Defense settles part of litigation challenging its involvement with the Boy Scouts of America |publisher=Usdoj.gov |date=16 November 2004 |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> and in 2005 the BSA agreed to transfer all Scouting units out of government entities such as public schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aclu-il.org/news/press/2005/03/national_boy_scout_organizatio.shtml|work=American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois|title=National Boy Scout Organization Agrees to End All Local Government Direct Sponsorship of Troops and Packs|accessdate=2006-03-02|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20081121085949/http://www.aclu-il.org/news/press/2005/03/national_boy_scout_organizatio.shtml|archivedate=2008-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/metro/20041116-115229-4427r.htm|work=Washington Times|title=Boy Scouts Jamboree to Stay at Army Base|accessdate=2006-03-02|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060419175333/http://www.washingtontimes.com/metro/20041116-115229-4427r.htm|archivedate=2006-04-19}}</ref>
Few politicians have been willing to identify as non-theists, since until recently such revelations would have been considered "political suicide",<ref name="SFC">{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/03/14/MNG7BOKV111.DTL |title=Stark's atheist views break political taboo|last=Marinucci|first=Carla|work=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=2009-03-12 | date=2007-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nysun.com/national/california-lawmaker-becomes-highest-ranking/50312/ |title=California Lawmaker Becomes Highest-Ranking Official To Say He's a Nonbeliever |publisher=Nysun.com |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> until [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] California Representative [[Pete Stark|Pete Stark's]] 2007 decision to come out as the first openly nontheistic member of Congress.<ref name="AHA"> {{cite web |url=http://www.americanhumanist.org/press/petestark.php |title=Humanists Praise Pete Stark for "Coming Out" as a Nontheist |publisher=American Humanist |accessdate=2009-03-17 }} </ref> In 2009, City Councilman [[Cecil Bothwell]] of Asheville, North Carolina was called "unworthy of his seat" because of his open atheism.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/12/14/critics-say-atheist-nc-city-councilman-unworthy-seat/ |title=Critics Say Atheist N.C. City councilman Unworthy of Seat |publisher=Fox News |date=7 April 2010 |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> Several polls have shown that about 50 percent of Americans would not vote for a qualified atheist for president.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.MotherJones.com/news/exhibit/2004/09/09_200.html | title = Faith in the System | journal = [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | month = September/October | year = 2004 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2007-03-11-politics-diversity-cover_N.htm|title=2008 race has the face of a changing America|last=Page|first=Susan|work=USA Today|accessdate=2009-03-13 | date=2007-03-12}}</ref> A 2006 study found that 40% of respondents characterized atheists as a group that did "not at all agree with my vision of American society", and that 48% would not want their child to marry an atheist. As [[child custody laws in the United States]], are often based on the "best interests of the child" principle, they leave family court judges ample room to consider a parent’s ideology when settling a custody case. W. Bush's son, [[George W. Bush]], acknowledged those who do not worship during a November 3, 2004 press conference when he said "I will be your president regardless of your faith... The constitutions of these six US states ban atheists from holding public office:
:Arkansas: ::"No person who denies the being of a God shall hold any office in the civil departments of this State, nor be competent to testify as a witness in any Court."<ref>{{cite book|title=Constitution of the State of Arkansas|url=http://www.arkleg.state.ar.us/assembly/Summary/ArkansasConstitution1874.pdf|publisher=Arkansas State Legislature|location=Little Rock, AR|accessdate=17 July 2012}}</ref> :Maryland: ::"That no religious test ought ever to be required as a qualification for any office of profit or trust in this State, other than a declaration of belief in the existence of God; nor shall the Legislature prescribe any other oath of office than the oath prescribed by this Constitution.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/43const/html/00dec.html|title=Constitution of Maryland|date=June 10, 2011|publisher=Maryland State Archives|accessdate=17 July 2012|location=Annapolis, MD}}</ref> :Mississippi: ::"No person who denies the existence of a Supreme Being shall hold any office in this state."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sos.ms.gov/links/ed_pubs/pubs/Mississippi_Constitution.pdf|title=Constitution of the State of Mississippi|publisher=Secretary of State, State of Mississippi|page=117|accessdate=17 July 2012|location=Jackson, MS}}</ref> :South Carolina: ::"No person who denies the existence of a Supreme Being shall hold any office under this Constitution."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scstatehouse.gov/scconstitution/a17.php|title=South Carolina Constitution Article 17 Section 4.|accessdate=2012-06-18}}</ref> :Tennessee: ::"No person who denies the being of God, or a future state of rewards and punishments, shall hold any office in the civil department of this state."<ref>{{cite book|title=Tennessee Blue Book 2011-2012|url=http://www.tn.gov/sos/bluebook/11-12/TS5_TNFoundingDocs.pdf|publisher=Secretary of State, State of Tennessee|location=Nashville, TN|chapter=Article IX, Disqualifications}}</ref> :Texas: ::"No religious test shall ever be required as a qualification to any office, or public trust, in this State; nor shall any one be excluded from holding office on account of his religious sentiments, provided he acknowledge the existence of a Supreme Being."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/Docs/CN/htm/CN.1.htm|title=Texas Constitution, Article 1, Section 4.|accessdate=2012-06-18}}</ref>
A seventh state constitution discriminates against atheists by affording special protection to theists only. :Pennsylvania: ::"No person who acknowledges the being of a God and a future state of rewards and punishments shall, on account of his religious sentiments, be disqualified to hold any office or place of trust or profit under this Commonwealth."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sites.state.pa.us/PA_Constitution.html | title=Pennsylvania Constitution, Article 1, Section 4.| accessdate=2012-10-10}}</ref>
===Islamic countries=== Atheists, or those accused of holding atheistic beliefs, may be subject to discrimination and persecution in some Islamic countries. According to popular interpretations of Islam, Muslims are not free to change religion or become an atheist: denying Islam and thus becoming an [[apostasy|apostate]] is traditionally punished by death in men and by life imprisonment in women. The death penalty for apostasy is apparent in a range of Islamic states including: [[Iran]],<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/3179465/Hanged-for-being-a-Christian-in-Iran.html The Telegraph, "Hanged for Being a Christian in Iran]</ref><ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/31/uk-iran-execution-apostasy-idUKTRE70U41D20110131 Reuters, "Iran hangs man convicted of apostasy"]</ref> [[Egypt]],<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2007/sep/17/supportingislamsapostates, "Supporting Islam's apostates"]</ref> [[Pakistan]],<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2007/sep/17/supportingislamsapostates, "Supporting Islam's apostates"]</ref> [[Somalia]],<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7833621.stm BBC news, "Somali executed for 'apostasy'"]</ref> [[United Arab Emirates]],<ref>http://freedomcenterstudents.org/2010/05/crimes-punishable-by-death-in-the-uae-include-apostasy/</ref> [[Qatar]],<ref name=barnabasfund>[http://www.barnabasfund.org/news/archives/article.php?ID_news_items=295 Copyright © 2007 Barnabas Fund | Islamic Teaching on the Consequences of Apostasy from Islam]</ref> [[Yemen]],<ref name=barnabasfund/> and [[Saudi Arabia]],<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2007/sep/17/supportingislamsapostates, "Supporting Islam's apostates"]</ref> although there have been no recently reported executions in Saudi Arabia.<ref>[http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/World/20060327/muslims_conversion_060327/ CTV news, "'Apostasy' laws widespread in Muslim world"], quote: "Islamic Shariah law considers conversion to any religion apostasy and most Muslim scholars agree the punishment is death. Saudi Arabia considers Shariah the law of the land, though there have been no reported cases of executions of converts from Islam in recent memory."</ref> Since an apostate can be considered a Muslim whose beliefs cast doubt on the Divine, and/or [[Koran]], claims of atheism and [[apostasy]] have been made against Muslim scholars and political opponents throughout history.<ref name="kamrava">{{cite book|last=Kamrava|first=Mehran|title=The new voices of Islam: reforming politics and modernity : a reader |publisher=I.B.Tauris|year=2006|pages=123–24|isbn=978-1-84511-275-2|url=http://books.google.com/?id=wTYJv7mwCoIC&pg=PA123}}</ref><ref name="isbn90-411-1105-0">{{cite book| last = Hamad|first= Ahmad| chapter= Legal plurality and legitimation of human rights abuses | editors = Al-Zwaini, Laila; Baudouin Dupret; Berger, Maurits | title = Legal pluralism in the Arab world | publisher = Kluwer Law International | location = The Hague | year = 1999 | page = 221 | isbn = 90-411-1105-0 | oclc = | url = http://books.google.com/?id=VAcOB1eMa5QC&pg=PA221 }}</ref><ref name="apost">{{cite book | author = Zaki Badawi, M.A.| chapter= Islam | title = Encyclopedia of religious freedom | editor= Cookson, Catharine| publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 2003 | pages = 204–8| isbn = 0-415-94181-4 | oclc = | url = http://books.google.com/?id=R0PrjC1Ar7gC&pg=PA206 }}</ref>
In Iran, atheists do not have any recognized legal status, and must declare that they are Muslim, Christian, Jewish or Zoroastrian, in order to claim some legal rights, including applying for entrance to university,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fidh.org/IMG/pdf/ir0108a.pdf|title=Discrimination against religious minorities in IRAN|date=August 2003|work=Fédération Internationale des Ligues des Droits de l`Homme and the Ligue de Défense des Droits de l’Homme en Iran|accessdate=2009-03-13}}</ref> or becoming a lawyer.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/asset/MDE13/045/2001/en/73a8bc2a-d8ae-11dd-ad8c-f3d4445c118e/mde130452001en.html |title=Iran: A legal system that fails to protect freedom of expression and association |publisher=Amnesty International |accessdate=2009-03-14 }} </ref> Similarly, [[Jordan]] requires atheists to associate themselves with a recognized religion for official identification purposes,<ref> {{cite web |url=http://2001-2009.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2008/108485.htm |title=International Religious Freedom Report 2008-Jordan |publisher= US of Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor |accessdate=2009-03-14 }} </ref> and atheists in [[Indonesia]] experience official discrimination in the context of registration of births and marriages, and the issuance of identity cards.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90137.htm |title=International Religious Freedom Report 2007-Indonesia |publisher= US of Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor |accessdate=2009-03-14 }} </ref> In [[Egypt]], intellectuals suspected of holding atheistic beliefs have been prosecuted by judicial and religious authorities. Novelist Alaa Hamad was convicted of publishing a book that contained atheistic ideas and apostasy that were considered to threaten national unity and social peace.<ref name="boyle">{{cite book|last=Boyle|first=Kevin|coauthors=Sheen, Juliet |title=Freedom of Religion and Belief: A World Report |publisher=Routledge |year=1997|page=30|isbn=978-0-415-15978-4|url=http://books.google.com/?id=MFUZkWWgOtMC&pg=RA1-PA30}}</ref><ref name="al">{{cite book | author =Al-Boray, Nagad | chapter= Egypt| title = Secrecy and Liberty: National Security, Freedom of Expression and Access to Information (International Studies in Human Rights) | publisher = Springer | location = Berlin | year = 1999 | isbn = 90-411-1191-3 | oclc = | url = http://books.google.com/?id=72IynQKXt3sC&pg=PA251}}</ref>
====Algeria==== The study of Islam is a requirement in public and private schools for every Algerian child, irrespective of his/her religion.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.algerie-dz.com/article841.html|title=Ecoles privées en Algérie : Plaidoyer pour le bilinguisme|language=French|accessdate=29 August 2010|date=30 June 2004|author=Djamila Kourta|work=[[El Watan]]}}</ref>
Atheist or agnostic men are prohibited from marrying Muslim women ([[Algerian Family Code]] I.II.31).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lexalgeria.net/droitdelafamille.htm |title=de beste bron van informatie over Lexalgeria. Deze website is te koop! |publisher=lexalgeria.net |date=2 January 2011 |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> A marriage is legally nullified by the apostasy of the husband (presumably from Islam, although this is not specified; Family Code I.III.33). Atheists and agnostics cannot inherit (Family Code III.I.138.).
===Other=== Compulsory religious instruction in [[Turkey|Turkish]] schools is also considered discriminatory towards atheists.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/47665e602.html |title= A Quest for Equality: Minorities in Turkey |year= 2007 |publisher= Minority Rights Group International |accessdate=2009-03-14 }} </ref>
